TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Sandy-skeletal, mixed Typic Cryaquents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Eachuston gravelly loam - grassland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--3 to 0 inches; undecomposed organic material, principally grass remains, roots, and leaves.
A1--0 to 4 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) gravelly loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; moderate fine granular structure; soft, very friable; 30 percent gravel; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.  (3 to 5 inches thick)
AC--4 to 8 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) gravelly loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure that parts to fine granules; soft, very friable; 30 percent gravel; common medium distinct mottles, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; neutral (pH 7.0); clear wavy boundary.  (3 to 5 inches thick)
IIC--8 to 60 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) very gravelly loamy sand, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; common medium distinct reddish brown (5YR 4/4) mottles; 60 percent gravel and some cobbles.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Jackson County, Colorado; 4/10 mile northwest of SE corner of Sec. 20, T. 7 N., R. 77 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature is about
40 degrees F. and mean summer temperature is about 53 degrees F.  The soil is 80 to 100 percent base saturated.  The control section is very gravelly loamy sand or sand.  Rock fragments range from 35 to 80 percent and are mainly less than 3 inches in diameter.  The A1 horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5 YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist, and chroma of 1 or 2 and has common medium distinct to many large prominent mottles.  It ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.  This horizon typically has granular structure but has subangular blocky structure in some pedons.  The C horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR and has common medium distinct to many large prominent mottles.  It ranges from slightly acid to mildly alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Juban, McKinney, and Stave series.  Juban soils are calcareous and have fine-loamy over sandy or sandy-skeletal control sections.  McKinney soils have a fine-loamy control section.  Stave soils have a sandy control section.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Eachuston soils are on nearly level to gently sloping flood plains and low terraces.  Slope gradients range from 0 to 6 percent.  The soil formed in very gravelly, coarse textured alluvial sediments.  At the type location the average annual precipitation is 10 inches with peak periods of precipitation during the spring and early summer.  Average annual temperature is
36 degrees F. and average summer temperature is 54 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Dobrow and Girardot soils.  Dobrow soils have coarse-loamy control sections and have mollic epipedons.  Girardot soils have fine-loamy control sections and are calcareous.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poor to very poorly drained; slow runoff; rapid permeability.  These soils have high water tables that stand at or near the surface of the ground most of the year.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used as native pastureland or as native hay meadow.  Principal native vegetation is timothy, sedges, bluegrass, and alsike clover.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  High mountain valleys of north-central Colorado.  The series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 10/73.
